clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Disease activity (follow up: range 4 months to 2 years; assessed with: ACR 20)

Risk of bias.rationales: Three studies at low risk of bias represent 60% of the weight.

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting harm.

Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Disease activity (follow up: range 4 months to 2 years; assessed with: DAS28 or DAS44 (lower values --> benefit) (values>0.2 are considered clinically important)

Risk of bias.rationales: Three studies at low risk of bias represent 60% of the weight.

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting harm. According to the Cochrane's handbook, Cohen suggested that SMD=0.2 be considered a 'small' effect size, 0.5 represents a 'medium' effect size and 0.8 a 'large' effect size. This means that if two groups' means do not differ by 0.2 standard deviations or more, the difference is trivial, even if it is statistically significant.

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): SMD 0.24 SD higher (0.1 higher to 0.38 higher)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Remission (follow up: range 4 months to 1 year; assessed with: DAS remission < 2.6 )

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting benefit.

Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias. Lack of allocation concealment and blinding.

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting harm.

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Radiographic progression (follow up: 6 months; assessed with: mTSS (Lower values – > benefit) (MCID 4.6)

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 0.17 higher (0.14 higher to 0.2 higher)(The studies ACT-RAY and SURPRISE found that the RR of developing no radiographic progression (change in mTSS ≤0.5) was 0.96 (95%CI 0.91 to 1.02), absolute risk reduction 34 fewer per 1000 (95%CI 76 fewer to 17 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Pain (follow up: range 4 months to 12 months; assessed with: VAS pain (0-100) (Lower values – > benefit) (MCID -11.9)

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 1.9 higher (0.3 lower to 4.1 higher)(The study ORAL Strategy found that the RR of improvement in pain VAS (0-100) ≥ 10 was 0.99 (95% CI 0.92 to 1.07), absolute risk reduction 8 fewer per 1000 (95%CI 62 fewer to 54 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Disability (follow up: range 4 months to 2 years; assessed with: HAQ-DI (Lower values – > benefit) (MCID -0.22)

Risk of bias.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious risk of bias in three studies representing 55% of the weight.

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 0 (0.06 lower to 0.07 higher)(The studies ADORE, ORAL strategy and Strand 2006, found that the RR of improvement in HAQ-DI (≥0.22 or ≥0.25 change from baseline) was 0.94 (95%CI 0.83 to 1.07), absolute risk reduction 39 fewer per 1000 (95%CI 112 fewer to 46 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Fatigue (follow up: 1 year; assessed with: FACIT-F (Higher values – > benefit) (MCID 15.9)

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 0.62 lower (1.84 lower to 0.6 higher)(The study ORAL Strategy found that the RR of improvement in FACIT-F≥ 4 was 0.92 (95% CI 0.83 to 1.01), absolute risk reduction 55 fewer per 1000 (95%CI 117 fewer to 7 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Quality of Life (follow up: 1 year; assessed with:  SF-36 MCS (Higher values – > benefit) (MCID 3.1)

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 0.97 lower (2.1 lower to 0.16 higher)(The study ORAL Strategy found that the RR of improvement in SF-36 MCS ≥ 2.5 was 0.94 (95% CI 0.84 to 1.05), absolute risk reduction 37 fewer per 1000 (95%CI 100 fewer to 31 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Quality of Life (follow up: 1 year; assessed with: SF-36 PCS (Higher values – > benefit) (MCID 4.4)

Effect.Absolute Effect (95% CI): MD 0.87 lower (1.9 lower to 0.16 higher)(The studies ADORE, ORAL strategy and Strand 2006, found that the RR of improvement in HAQ-DI (≥0.22 or ≥0.25 change from baseline) was 0.94 (95%CI 0.83 to 1.07), absolute risk reduction 39 fewer per 1000 (95%CI 112 fewer to 46 more).)
Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by one level due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting no effect and values suggesting benefit. According to the Cochrane's handbook, Cohen suggested that SMD=0.2 be considered a 'small' effect size, 0.5 represents a 'medium' effect size and 0.8 a 'large' effect size. This means that if two groups' means do not differ by 0.2 standard deviations or more, the difference is trivial, even if it is statistically significant.

clinical_question: Should patients with RA on DMARD(s) who are NOT at target switch to another DMARD versus add a 2nd DMARD?
population: Patients with RA on non-biologic DMARD(s) who are not at target
outcome: Withdrawal due to adverse events (follow up: range 3 months to 2 years)

Risk of bias.rationales: Four studies at high risk of bias represent 40% of the weight. This is accounted for when downgrading for imprecision.

Imprecision.rationales: Downgraded by two levels due to serious imprecision. Confidence interval includes both values suggesting benefit and values suggesting harm.

Effect.Abbreviations: CI: Confidence interval; RR: Risk ratio; MD: Mean difference; HR: Hazard Ratio
